ui.stage
Class MainStage

java.lang.Object
  java.awt.Component
      java.awt.Container
          javax.swing.JComponent
              javax.swing.JPanel
                  ui.stage.MainStage
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.awt.event.ActionListener, java.awt.image.ImageObserver, java.awt.KeyEventDispatcher, java.awt.MenuContainer, java.io.Serializable, java.util.EventListener, javax.accessibility.Accessible
public class MainStage
extends javax.swing.JPanel
implements java.awt.event.ActionListener, java.awt.KeyEventDispatcher

The MainStage is where the action happens. It is a JPanel that displays the image that is currently on the large flat-panel display, as buttons to control the retreating and advancing of the queue.

Author:
carl
See Also:
Serialized Form

Constructor Detail

MainStage

public MainStage(OnDemandMedia parent,
                 java.lang.String address,
                 boolean attemptConnection)
Constructs the main stage. This is where the user sees the currently displayed image and is also able to control the advancement and retreat of this image.

Parameters:
parent - the OnDemandMedia object in which this MainStage resides.
address - The string corresponding to the address of the computer driving the large flat-panel display.
attemptConnection - true if we should try to connect to the computer driving the main display.
Method Detail

showImage

public void showImage(MediaFile newImage,
                      java.lang.Object comesFrom)
Sets an image on the central stage. If given null, leaves the main stage empty.

Parameters:
newImage -

actionPerformed

public void actionPerformed(java.awt.event.ActionEvent event)
Listens for a button press. When a button is pressed, this method determines whether it was the previous or the next button that has been pressed.

Specified by:
actionPerformed in interface java.awt.event.ActionListener
Parameters:
event - the action (previous or next) that relates to this event

dispatchKeyEvent

public boolean dispatchKeyEvent(java.awt.event.KeyEvent event)
Listens for an "up" or "down" key event. If the up or down key has been typed (pressed and released) then we advance or retreat the strip.

Specified by:
dispatchKeyEvent in interface java.awt.KeyEventDispatcher
Parameters:
event - the KeyEvent that we are checking.
